Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Smart, sustainable and self-healing anticorrosive pigment additive
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project will result in the development of smart, self-healing nanocapsules as anticorrosive pigment additive for commercialization of sustainable, economical and metal free acrylic, epoxy or polyurethane based anticorrosive coatings. The nanocapsule additive based anticorrosive coating will meet and exceed the performance of solvent and heavy metals based coatings and disrupt the current technology paradigms by delivering a sustainable and efficient anticorrosive coating technology into the market. The cost to fix or replace corroded structures in the US alone is a staggering $500 Billions/year that is compounded by the toxic environmental impact on account of the use of heavy metals such as, chromium, zinc and lead as anticorrosion pigments. This project will directly address these two important unmet industry needs. For example, the technology will replace heavy metals and deliver corrosion protection exactly when and where it is needed. This will increase the life-time of the coatings, decrease maintenance costs, and reduce the energy and labor costs. This novel technology is simple, scalable, and will find application across multiple industry sectors such as construction, oil & gas, architecture, defense, aerospace etc.

The intellectual merit of this project is the development of smart, self-healing, polymer based nanocapsules as pigment additives in anticorrosive coatings. Corrosion is an electrochemical process and is induced by corrosive ions in the environment. At the onset of corrosion, the electrochemical potential at the corroding site changes. Hence, in this project polymer based nanocapsules will be developed that will inhibit corrosion by multiple mechanisms. The nanocapsules themselves will prevent corrosion by acting as ionic barrier between metal and toxic ions as well as by anodic passivation. If the passivation or the barrier effect fails due to scratch or mechanical damage and the metal starts to corrode, the change in electrochemical potential on the corroding metal surface will activate the nanocapsules to release corrosion inhibitors encapsulated in the capsules at the corroding site. This phase I project will develop a method to synthesize smart, self-healing nanocapsules encapsulated with corrosion inhibitor. These nanocapsules will deliver a next-generation, water-based, acrylic, epoxy or polyurethane based anticorrosive coatings into the market.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF Phase I project successfully developed hollow microcapsules of polymer encapsulated with corrosion inhibiting agent for use as anticorrosive pigment additive in coatings. The microcapsules were encapsulated with a variety of corrosion inhibiting and rust converting agents such as mercaptobenzothiazole, mercaptobenzotraizole, triethanol amine, Halox 570, trihydroxybenzoic acid, tannic acid etc. The microcapsules when added as additives (3 wt%) in anticorrosive coatings, prevents corrosion of coated metal by multiple mechanism. For example, the microcapsules prevent corrosion by acting as ionic barrier between metal and toxic ions as well as by anodic passivation of metals. If the passivation or the barrier effect fails due to scratch or mechanical damage and the metal starts to corrode, the change in electrochemical potential on the corroding metal surface activates the microcapsules to release corrosion inhibitors encapsulated in the microcapsules at the corroding site to seal and protect the scratched/corroding site from further corrosion. 

The hollow microcapsules were synthesized by aqueous oxidative polymerization of monomers  Several factors such as (a) reaction temperature (b) concentration of monomer (c) concentration of oxidant (d) monomer:oxidant ratio (e) exposed surface; affected the final morphology of the polymer formed and therefore we carefully optimized all the above-mentioned factors and developed a synthesis method to obtain hollow microcapsules with uniform morphology of diameter in 500 nm – 1500 nm range.

We also developed three methods to encapsulate corrosion inhibiting agent inside microcapsules (a) solvent evaporation (b) in-situ (c) precipitation method. Corrosion inhibiting agents were successfully incorporated inside microcapsules without destroying the capsule morphology. The corrosion inhibitor loading percentage inside capsules were 15 – 35 wt%.

We tested the corrosion protection performance of our microcapsule additives by formulating acrylic and epoxy based anticorrosive coatings containing 3 wt% polymer microcapsules loaded with corrosion inhibitor. These anticorrosive coatings were coated on steel panels and the corrosion inhibition performance was tested using ASTM B117 salt fog test method. The performance of these anticorrosive coatings was very impressive even after 2000 hours of salt-fog corrosion test and therefore has a great potential to replace heavy metals in anticorrosive coatings. 

Our technology will enable sustainable, economical and heavy metal free anticorrosive coatings into the market. Our technology based anticorrosive coatings will meet and exceed the performance of solvent and heavy metal based coatings and disrupt the current technology paradigms by delivering a sustainable and efficient anticorrosive coating technology into the market. The cost to fix or replace corroded structures in the US alone is a staggering $500 Billions/year that is compounded by the toxic environmental impact on account of the use of heavy metals such as, chromium, zinc and lead as anticorrosion pigments. Our technology will directly address these two important unmet industry needs. For example, our technology will replace heavy metals and the self-healing nature of our technology will deliver corrosion protection exactly when and where it is needed. This will increase the life-time of the coatings, decrease maintenance costs, and reduce the energy and labor costs.  Our novel technology is simple, scalable, and will find application across multiple industry sectors such as defense, aerospace, construction, architecture etc.

  

 


Last Modified: 01/29/2019
Modified by: Sumedh P Surwade

The microcapsules were encapsulated with a variety of corrosion inhibiting and rust converting agents such as mercaptobenzothiazole, mercaptobenzotraizole, triethanol amine, Halox 570, trihydroxybenzoic acid, tannic acid etc. The microcapsules when added as additives (3 wt%) in anticorrosive coatings, prevents corrosion of coated metal by multiple mechanism. For example, the microcapsules prevent corrosion by acting as ionic barrier between metal and toxic ions as well as by anodic passivation of metals. If the passivation or the barrier effect fails due to scratch or mechanical damage and the metal starts to corrode, the change in electrochemical potential on the corroding metal surface activates the microcapsules to release corrosion inhibitors encapsulated in the microcapsules at the corroding site to seal and protect the scratched/corroding site from further corrosion. Corrosion inhibiting agents were successfully incorporated inside microcapsules without destroying the capsule morphology. The corrosion inhibitor loading percentage inside capsules were 15 – 35 wt%. We tested the corrosion protection performance of our microcapsule additives by formulating acrylic and epoxy based anticorrosive coatings containing 3 wt% polymer microcapsules loaded with corrosion inhibitor. These anticorrosive coatings were coated on steel panels and the corrosion inhibition performance was tested using ASTM B117 salt fog test method. The performance of these anticorrosive coatings was very impressive even after 2000 hours of salt-fog corrosion test and therefore has a great potential to replace heavy metals in anticorrosive coatings. Our technology based anticorrosive coatings will meet and exceed the performance of solvent and heavy metal based coatings and disrupt the current technology paradigms by delivering a sustainable and efficient anticorrosive coating technology into the market. The cost to fix or replace corroded structures in the US alone is a staggering $500 Billions/year that is compounded by the toxic environmental impact on account of the use of heavy metals such as, chromium, zinc and lead as anticorrosion pigments. Our technology will directly address these two important unmet industry needs. For example, our technology will replace heavy metals and the self-healing nature of our technology will deliver corrosion protection exactly when and where it is needed. This will increase the life-time of the coatings, decrease maintenance costs, and reduce the energy and labor costs. Our novel technology is simple, scalable, and will find application across multiple industry sectors such as defense, aerospace, construction, architecture etc. Last Modified: 01/29/2019 Submitted by: Sumedh P Surwade
